newsitem.title: USA: Bayer sees deal boosting U.S. OTC business.
newsitem.headline: Bayer sees deal boosting U.S. OTC business.

text.p: Bayer AG said on Monday the addition of two drugs gained in a joint-venture deal with Roche Holding AG would add "at least" $200 million to Bayer's U.S. over-the-counter drug business in 1997.
The venture will include Roche's Aleve analgesic and Femstat 3 for vaginal yeast infections.
Bayer's U.S. consumer care division had sales of about $600 million in 1995, unit president Gary Balkema said.
"The addition of Aleve and Femstat 3 is projected to add at least $200 million next year, taking us to beyond $800 million," he said in a conference call.

A Bayer spokesman in Germany said total sales of the joint venture, which will include Bayer's Actron and Vanquish analgesics, Midol menstrual pain reliever and Mycelex-7 vaginal yeast infection treatment, will be about $275 million in its early years.
The venture does not include Bayer asprin or other Bayer brands including Alka-Seltzer, One-A-Day and Flintstones vitamins.
Balkema said the deal will move Bayer into the No. 3 spot among U.S. OTC health care companies, behind Johnson and Johnson and American Home Products Corp.
He said that prior to the deal, Bayer stood at about No. 6.
"Our intent is to build both internally and externally to be one of the premier players here in the U.S.," he said.
Balkema said Bayer expected Aleve to face generic, private-label competition starting in early 1997 in the U.S.
"We're expecting that (and) we'll obviously keep that in mind during our marketing efforts for next year," he said.
He said Bayer had not made any decisions "in the long term" on advertising agencies for the joint venture.
"Obviously our first priority is to work with the current agency lineup and continue to have what we're calling a seamless transition," he said.
Earlier, Bayer and Roche said the deal needed cartel authority approval.
